articles.headline: In Toyota Mess, Lesson for Japan
articles.snippet: Economists said that Toyota’s troubles show that economic change is urgently needed in Japan.
articles.abstract: Economists said that Toyota’s troubles show that economic change is urgently needed in Japan.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Toyota’s president, Akio Toyoda, apologized for the recalls that have marred Toyota’s reputation, he talked not just about his company’s fate, but also his nation’s.

articles.headline: Paperwork Hinders Airlifts of Ill Haitian Children
articles.snippet: Doctors and aid workers are wrestling with proving that they are not illegally transporting children, whose risk of dying is rising while the paperwork awaits.
articles.abstract: Doctors and aid workers are wrestling with proving that they are not illegally transporting children, whose risk of dying is rising while the paperwork awaits.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Private medical evacuations of critically injured Haitian children to the United States for treatment have largely stopped because aid workers, doctors and government officials are worried about being accused of kidnapping if they transport the children without first getting paperwork that is slow to arrive or is unavailable.

articles.headline: S.E.C. Enforcers Focus on Avoiding Madoff Repeat
articles.snippet: Robert S. Khuzami, the head of enforcement, must restore confidence that the S.E.C. can police Wall Street.
articles.abstract: Robert S. Khuzami, the head of enforcement, must restore confidence that the S.E.C. can police Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Bernard L. Madoff haunts these corridors like the He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named of Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: Bills Stalled, Hospitals Fear Rising Unpaid Care
articles.snippet: While the debate continues in Washington, health care systems nationwide struggle to offset money spent to treat patients who cannot afford to pay their bills.
articles.abstract: While the debate continues in Washington, health care systems nationwide struggle to offset money spent to treat patients who cannot afford to pay their bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama says he aims to keep trying. But what happens if the health care legislation cannot be revived, and tens of millions of uninsured Americans continue without coverage?

articles.headline: Shareholders Deciding a Dividend
articles.snippet: The dividend, which private equity firms routinely paid to themselves until the economy turned against them, is back.
articles.abstract: The dividend, which private equity firms routinely paid to themselves until the economy turned against them, is back.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wouldn’t it be great if we could turn back the clock to 2007?

articles.headline: Optimism Persists in a Kentucky Town Where a Carmaker Brought Jobs
articles.snippet: As production resumes this week in Georgetown, Ky., and other American cities where Toyota builds cars, people are eager to see its recall problems blow over.
articles.abstract: As production resumes this week in Georgetown, Ky., and other American cities where Toyota builds cars, people are eager to see its recall problems blow over.
articles.lead_paragraph: GEORGETOWN, Ky.  Before Toyota arrived here more than two decades ago, Georgetown was a sleepy town of 10,000. Its population has since swelled to 25,000, and most of those people owe their livelihood to the sprawling Toyota plant outside of town on Cherry Blossom Way.

articles.headline: As Data Flows In, the Dollars Flow Out
articles.snippet: The average American is expected to spend nearly $1,000 this year on services like cable, Internet and video games.
articles.abstract: The average American is expected to spend nearly $1,000 this year on services like cable, Internet and video games.
articles.lead_paragraph: John Anderson and Sharon Rapoport estimate they spend $400 a month, or close to $5,000 a year, keeping their family of four entertained at home.

articles.headline: From Right of Radio Dial, a Challenge to McCain
articles.snippet: Challenged by J. D. Hayworth from the airwaves, and soon in a primary, John McCain has moved to the right.
articles.abstract: Challenged by J. D. Hayworth from the airwaves, and soon in a primary, John McCain has moved to the right.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX  J. D. Hayworth is a large man, and to compensate for his indulgences, he hits the elliptical trainer every morning at 4, zipping along to an incongruous soundtrack of Elvis Costello, Frank Sinatra and old advertising jingles.

articles.headline: Arrests by Iran Are a Bid to Quell Wide Protests
articles.snippet: Iranian security officials were believed to have arrested as many as 1,000 people in the past two months, a rights group said.
articles.abstract: Iranian security officials were believed to have arrested as many as 1,000 people in the past two months, a rights group said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  In recent weeks, security officials have unleashed an epidemic of arrests across Iran in an effort to neutralize the political opposition, silence critical voices and head off widespread protests when the nation observes the anniversary of the revolution on Thursday, Iran analysts inside and outside the country said.

articles.headline: Talk of Assistance for Greece Propels Markets
articles.snippet: Whispers that a rescue for Greece might be near touched off a broad rally in European stocks, bonds and the euro, as well as American markets.
articles.abstract: Whispers that a rescue for Greece might be near touched off a broad rally in European stocks, bonds and the euro, as well as American markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hopes that the wealthy nations of Europe would come to the aid of Greece galvanized financial markets on Tuesday and, for a day at least, soothed fears that the economic troubles on the fringes of the Continent might spread.
articles.byline: By Javier C. Hernández and Jack Ewing
